posts.post_content:
Why not this?  
[Puresteel Paladin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Puresteel Paladin) with metalcraft to make it cost ![0](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=0&type=symbol) to equip.  
3 [Etherium Sculptor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Etherium Sculptor)s to make it cost ![0](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=0&type=symbol) to play.  
[Battered Golem](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Battered Golem) which gets a free untap when this comes in.  
Damage your opponent infinitely, refill your hand as much as you wish, and...  
Profit!  
  
And yes, I know that there are better combinations that cost less mana to kill your opponent faster, but are THOSE combinations using the lowest rated card IN THE GAME to do it? I think not.

Posted By: TheSwarm (7/18/2011 6:59:32 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
There are many older cards which read as hideously inefficient today, but were somewhat forgivable at a time when WotC didn't know the game as well as it does today, or were experimenting with a new mechanic. I can at least understand where they were coming from in most cases.  
  
What the hell is Razor Boomerang's excuse?  
  
For a card from (at this writing) the newest set, this is inexplicable. It's so *obviously* horrid it doesn't even have the excuse of being a skill-tester. If it *didn't* return to your hand, it still wouldn't see constructed play and would be at most a mid-pack pick in draft; as printed, it's a complete waste of cardboard.
posts.html:
There are many older cards which read as hideously inefficient today, but were somewhat forgivable at a time when WotC didn't know the game as well as it does today, or were experimenting with a new mechanic. I can at least understand where they were coming from in most cases.

What the hell is Razor Boomerang's excuse?

For a card from (at this writing) the newest set, this is inexplicable. It's so obviously horrid it doesn't even have the excuse of being a skill-tester. If it didn't return to your hand, it still wouldn't see constructed play and would be at most a mid-pack pick in draft; as printed, it's a complete waste of cardboard.

posts.post_content: Well, it's an obvious 0.5/5, but there are still ways to win with this (i.e., [Palladium Myr](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Palladium Myr) and two [Myr Galvanizer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Myr Galvanizer)s). There are, shockingly enough, worse cards. [Wood Elemental](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wood Elemental) and [Mudhole](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mudhole) come to mind. This is a terrible card, yes, but it's not the absolute worst. Just bottom-five material.

posts.post_content:
there are to many flaws in this card.  
1. its mana cost is too high for the multiple draw backs( equip cost, deals only 1 damage , and comes back to hand).  
  
2. it should had been 2 - 3 damage done to target creature, that would had been at least a good draft card but instead it pings either a player or creature for 5 mana.  
  
3. it all ready has 5 mana to the cost why would we have to tap our creature, that is a little too much.
